results.abstract: Russian space agency turns down potential space tourist, South African tycoon Mark Shuttleworth, for being too demanding (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Space Tourist Is Rejected

results.snippet: The beleaguered space agency turned down a potential tourist for being too demanding, news agencies reported. The space chief, Yuri Koptev, said Mark Shuttleworth, 27, a South African tycoon who spent the summer at the astronaut training center in...
results.lead_paragraph: The beleaguered space agency turned down a potential tourist for being too demanding, news agencies reported. The space chief, Yuri Koptev, said Mark Shuttleworth, 27, a South African tycoon who spent the summer at the astronaut training center in Russia, wanted a miniumum two-week trip and a second free trip if the first attempt to dock with the International Space Station failed. Dennis Tito, a California millionaire, reportedly paid the agency $20 million to become the first space tourist last spring. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

results.abstract: Warren Leary article on Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral as American icon; photo (M)

headline.main: American Treasures: Florida; Where shuttles are launched, and astronauts remembered

results.snippet: The Kennedy Space Center is the site of some of America's greatest technological achievements, as well as a symbol of how the nation can rise above adversity. Each year, more than two million visitors make the pilgrimage to Cape Canaveral, Fla., just...
results.lead_paragraph: The Kennedy Space Center is the site of some of America's greatest technological achievements, as well as a symbol of how the nation can rise above adversity. Each year, more than two million visitors make the pilgrimage to Cape Canaveral, Fla., just 45 minutes east of Orlando. The center is the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's main base for sending humans and their robotic surrogates beyond the Earth to explore the next great unknown. While it enshrines rich history, Cape Canaveral is very much living in the present: the Kennedy Space Center and the nearby Cape Canaveral Air Force Station remain working installations.

results.abstract: Elvis Mitchell reviews science-fiction movie musical The American Astronaut, written and directed by Cory McAbee (M)

headline.main: Sci-Fi Slapstick, With Spacemen Bursting Into Song

results.snippet: The unremittingly eccentric science-fiction musical ''The American Astronaut'' is not a picture that is likely to have you walking out of the theater murmuring that there's nothing else like it. What you may say after sitting through it is that...
results.lead_paragraph: The unremittingly eccentric science-fiction musical ''The American Astronaut'' is not a picture that is likely to have you walking out of the theater murmuring that there's nothing else like it. What you may say after sitting through it is that you've never seen so many kinds of leftovers crammed between the same two slices of bread. Its purview is emphatically perverse, a salute to the Midnight Movie, a cultural land mass that spawned John Waters and David Lynch. ''Astronaut,'' which soars as much as it crashes, made the rounds on the film festival circuit this year, and it's easy to see why none of the mini-majors or ersatz boutique studios picked it up; they wouldn't have known what to do with the kinds of reactions this singular film causes. (It is being released by Artistic License Films and BNS Productions.)

results.abstract: NASA will increase security at nation's space centers in wake of Sept 11 terrorist attacks; will also fly thousands of American flags into space and then present them to survivors and families of victims; space shuttle flights will continue on schedule, at rate of abut one a month in near future (M)

headline.main: NASA to Tighten Security and Offer Comfort to Attack Survivors

results.snippet: NASA is responding to last month's terrorist attacks with increased security at the nation's space centers and plans to fly thousands of American flags into space, then present them to survivors and the families of victims.    The space agency's...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA is responding to last month's terrorist attacks with increased security at the nation's space centers and plans to fly thousands of American flags into space, then present them to survivors and the families of victims. The space agency's administrator, Daniel S. Goldin, said in an interview this week that NASA was not only increasing security at its sites, but was also carrying out far-reaching security plans that might take years to complete. He declined to detail any security measures, but said the agency hoped to receive some special antiterrorist money recently approved by Congress.

results.abstract: Lisa Ristow, who works at NASA in Houston, and Mark Polansky, astronaut, are wed in San Antonio; photos (M)
results.snippet: MOMENTS before he was to be married, Mark Polansky had a flashback. The astronaut, 45, remembered lying on his back last February in the space shuttle Atlantis, counting the seconds to liftoff.     ''I had all the same feelings -- the tremendous...
results.lead_paragraph: MOMENTS before he was to be married, Mark Polansky had a flashback. The astronaut, 45, remembered lying on his back last February in the space shuttle Atlantis, counting the seconds to liftoff. ''I had all the same feelings -- the tremendous rush, the fear, the need to get on with it -- except this time I knew the mission wasn't one single spectacular event in space,'' Mr. Polansky said. ''This was about the rest of my life.''

results.abstract: Army uniforms and Uncle Sam suits take lead in choice of Halloween costumes among New York City youngsters in wake of terrorist attacks; photos (M) (Pulse column)

headline.main: Like Mom And Dad: Good-Guy Costumes

results.snippet: This Halloween, it has become a trick to know how to treat, as parents struggle to find their children costumes that carry a lower scare factor. In particular, boys' costumes, which traditionally tend toward a guts-and-gore theme, are being toned...
results.lead_paragraph: This Halloween, it has become a trick to know how to treat, as parents struggle to find their children costumes that carry a lower scare factor. In particular, boys' costumes, which traditionally tend toward a guts-and-gore theme, are being toned down. And while fire and police outfits were the immediate favorites in September, more recently a variety of other patriotic costumes have become the top choice: army uniforms and Uncle Sam suits are leading the pack. ''People are now seeking looks that show pride in New York and in America,'' said Sharon Sternheim, owner of Zittles toy store on Madison Avenue and 76th Street. ''Last week, we sold out of military camouflage, the American flag and the Statue of Liberty within days.'' According to Ms. Sternheim, parents who prefer less violent or nationalistic looks for their offspring are opting for costumes of astronauts ($35), NASA pilots ($35) and American legends like Davy Crockett ($65). And while standards like Superman and Batman are having moderate success, Ms. Sternheim said, at the moment customers ''want real-life heroes, not make-believe ones.''

results.snippet: For Artists Starting Out  TOMORROW -- Young people in theater, dance and film will be supported by a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria that will raise money for the Princess Grace Foundation. It provides grants to promising young artists, and this year,...
results.lead_paragraph: For Artists Starting Out TOMORROW -- Young people in theater, dance and film will be supported by a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria that will raise money for the Princess Grace Foundation. It provides grants to promising young artists, and this year, half of the proceeds from the gala will be donated to children of those killed in the Sept. 11 attacks. The black-tie evening begins at 7 with cocktails, with dinner at 8 and dancing to the music of the Starlight Orchestra. Tickets, $600, from (212) 317-1470. Balanchine's Work TUESDAY -- Balanchine's ''Symphony in C'' will be among the works performed in the opening of the American Ballet Theater's fall season, at City Center, 131 West 55th Street. The evening, to help the company's performances and educational programs, begins at 7 with the performance. Dinner will follow at the University Club, 1 West 54th Street, at 9:30. Tickets, $600, from (212) 477-3030 ext. 3239.

results.abstract: In this lesson, students act as teams of scientists to explore environmental and geological conditions on other planets in our solar system, comparing their findings to information about Earth. They then propose technologies that might assist in supporting human life on those planets and present their ideas at a 'scientific conference.'
results.snippet: In this lesson, students act as teams of scientists to explore environmental and geological conditions on other planets in our solar system, comparing their findings to information about Earth. They then propose technologies that might assist in...

byline.original: By RACHEL MCCLAIN and ANDREA PERELMAN

results.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

results.abstract: Russian Soyuz spaceship carrying two Russian and one French astronaut dock with International Space Station, and Prime Min Lionel Jospin, on visit to Moscow, greets them by radio from Russian mission control center outside capital (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Moscow: Greetings To Space Station

results.snippet: A Russian Soyuz spaceship carrying two Russian and one French astronaut docked with the International Space Station, and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, on a visit to Moscow, greeted them by radio from the Russian mission control center outside the...
results.lead_paragraph: A Russian Soyuz spaceship carrying two Russian and one French astronaut docked with the International Space Station, and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, on a visit to Moscow, greeted them by radio from the Russian mission control center outside the capital. The three astronauts will replace the space station's escape vehicle and conduct experiments involving weightlessness during the eight-day stay. The French astronaut, Claudie Haigner√©, is the first French citizen to visit the station. Michael Wines (NYT)

results.abstract: Dr Vasily P Mishin, who helped preside over Soviet Union's failed effort to beat United States to Moon, dies at age 84; photo (M)

headline.main: Vasily Mishin, 84; Led Soviet Race to Moon

results.snippet: Dr. Vasily P. Mishin, who helped preside over the Soviet Union's failed effort to beat the United States to the Moon, died on Oct. 10 in Moscow. He was 84.    The death was reported by the Russian news media. He is survived by his wife, Nina...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Vasily P. Mishin, who helped preside over the Soviet Union's failed effort to beat the United States to the Moon, died on Oct. 10 in Moscow. He was 84. The death was reported by the Russian news media. He is survived by his wife, Nina Andreyevna Mishina, and three daughters.
